title: Dublin R: #GlobalR: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science March Meetup  [Virtual] , Ireland, Europe
description:
This is an external event. To RSVP - go to https://www.meetup.com/Newcastle-Upon-Tyne-Data-Science-Meetup/events/275548174/

Alastair Rushworth (Tesco Bank)

Title: Exploring EDA with R

Abstract: Exploratory data analysis (aka EDA) is one of the most important tools in the data scientist‚Äôs toolkit, while also being one of the hardest to codify and teach. EDA is often understood as an exercise undertaken at the beginning of a data science project, to expose insights and patterns that support, and eventually give way to more formal modelling or statistical analysis. But is this sufficient, or is there more to EDA than that? In this talk I will attempt to dig deeper into what EDA is for and how it can support an iterative process of learning and discovery, while also demonstrating some of the great R packages and tools that I have found useful along the way.

Matthew Higgs

Title: What can data scientists learn from data-driven responses to Covid-19?

Abstract: Data-driven responses to Covid-19 have been developed at speed across the public sector, academia, and commercial sector - leading to a range of successes, failures, and opportunities for lessons to be learned. At the ‚ÄòObservatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19‚Äô (omddac.org.uk) we are analysing key data-driven responses to Covid-19 and collating lessons learned by way of stakeholder interviews, case study analysis, and representative public surveys. In this talk, I will highlight some key findings from our stakeholder interviews and reflect on the role of data science during the Covid-19 pandemic. I will discuss successful applications of data science, ethical issues to be aware of, and what stakeholders *really* think about working with data scientists.

Bio: Matthew Higgs MMath, PhD is a Lecturer in the Department of Computing and Information Sciences at Northumbria University and a Co-Investigator on the UKRI-funded project ‚ÄòObservatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19‚Äô (omddac.org.uk). Since completing his PhD in Computational Statistics and Machine Learning at University College London in 2011, Matthew has worked in technical and non-technical roles in academia, the commercial sector, and the public sector - with a focus on managing diverse stakeholders and developing data-driven products and solutions.

Description:
officeverse : a set of packages to ease the production of Word and PowerPoint documents

## Abstract

officeverse : a set of packages to ease the production of Word and PowerPoint documents

The officer package has been developed to facilitate the production of Word documents and PowerPoint presentations with R.

The initial project was to offer an alternative solution to SAS ODS for tabular and graphical reports produced in Word for one of my clients. The range of functionalities has expanded and some very interesting extensions have been created. There is the officedown package that increases the layout capabilities of R Markdown when the output is Word, the rvg package to create editable vector graphics, the flextable package to make nice tables.

In this presentation, you will see how to use the package to produce PowerPoint presentations and Word documents. Its role as a foundation for other packages and new documentation will be discussed. It will also be an opportunity for David to present the officedown package for the first time.

## Speaker

David Gohel is the founder of ArData, a French company providing R expertise, R training and consulting in data sciences. He is the author of R packages, most popular are officer, flextable, rvg and ggiraph.

He is a data scientist and software engineer. His professional experiences led him to face many challenges related to the data of organizations, which he has always managed with solutions involving R software.

"Analysing Political Speeches in R: Some Approaches"

Abstract: Legislative debate transcripts can provide unique insights into politics and policy. They can be used to identify popular topics among different legislators, reveal party factions that do not show up in voting behaviour, and longitudinal changes in the language used to discuss certain topics, amongst other things. In this webinar I'll discuss some approaches and potential pitfalls to analysing legislative debate, using the British House of Commons as an example.

Biography: Evan Odell is a junior data consultant at Pandata and R programmer, based in Berlin. Evan has written numerous R packages, primarily for accessing and processing data, and created a dataset of UK House of Commons speeches available as a single RDS or CSV file. He has previously worked for Disability Rights UK, Queen's University and as a freelancer for London Business School.

Title: Social Media Analytics around Covid-19: A Case-Study of Misinformation

N.B. This talk will have more emphasis on Python packages.

Abstract: Covid-19 has created a tremendous impact in our world not just offline but also online. A particularly dangerous phenomenon is that of misinformation of which there are various types such as conspiracy theories, rumors, propaganda etc. We performed an analysis of tweets posted on Twitter regarding the famous conspiracy around 5g and its link to covid-19 using a famous technique from within natural language processing. This technique known as Word Embeddings is part of Python Gensim library and this talk will present a walk-through demonstration of that.

title: R-Ladies RTP: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

The dataset we will explore will be posted before we meet.

Agenda:
7:00 - 7:15 pm Meet & Greet
7:15 - 8:30 pm #tidytuesday
8:30 - 9:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

For this week, we will be looking at data related to the Bechdel Test. See https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2021/2021-03-09/readme.md

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a cozy beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

They will also be able to explain basic R syntax (e.g, "(" versus "["), data types (e.g., character versus integer), and programming concepts (e.g., functions versus packages). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Sheila at [masked] at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

The idea is to go through this book so that each chapter will be read
and presented by a certain person. Besides presentation and discussion, we will go through the exercises at the end of each chapter together.

Our first meeting will be on Sunday, March 28 from 3pm Tbilisi time. We will introduce the idea of the bookclub and discuss the next steps. Also, we will introduce the first chapter of the book. You are welcome to attend!

Please RSVP on Meetup or sign up at this link (even if you want to attend as a listener only):
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1lufZ5eKEeNyinYbPqytVchdbkx5SwS6eKVfnIvEoqXk/

If you're new to R-Ladies Seattle, please review the R-Ladies code of conduct:

The leadership, mentoring & teaching roles within this Community are held exclusively by minority genders (majority gender speakers may be allowed/invited as one-off guests in exceptional circumstances at the leadership team's discretion). Due to unexpected demand, we have opened learning participation to all genders, dependent on initial and on-going vetting by the leadership team. However, the stated priority of the R-Ladies communities is the development & support specifically of those identifying as a minority gender, and we, therefore, reserve the right to guard this interest through whatever measures the leadership team deem appropriate. Anyone involved with R-Ladies Seattle is expected to fully respect each other, the mandate of this community, and the goodwill on which R-Ladies is founded, or face expulsion/a penalty of any form, at the discretion of the leadership team. Full community guidelines are found here: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki ...

title: useR Group in San Luis Obispo County: Introduction to Computational Thinking and Ethics in Data Science  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: useR Group in San Luis Obispo County
description:
This Spring, Cal Poly's Data Science Initiative is running a series of python-based Data Science workshops for faculty professional development.

We are able to open a limited number of spots to the general public. You can sign up through the PyData SLO Meetup listing: https://www.meetup.com/PydataSLO/events/276975128/

Please see the description below for the first workshop, Introduction to Computational Thinking and Ethics for Data Science.

There is no fee for this workshop; however, we are asking that you make a donation to the Cal Poly Black Student Scholarship Fund (https://www.calfund.org/calpolyblackstudentfund/) in lieu of a workshop fee. The suggested donation is $25.

---

This half day (3.5 hour) training workshop aims to introduce researchers to computational thinking and the ethics of data science and computing.

Programming is a powerful and engaging tool in science, however, just learning syntax can be daunting and amorphous without starting with the basics of computational thinking. We aim to make explicit some of the `habits of mind' of computer scientists along with introducing some foundations and motivation for including ethical considerations with any computational project (especially those involving data and conclusions about data).

Topics include: an introduction to computational thinking (data and small patterns), the role and importance of ethical considerations in computing and data science and hand-on activities practicing with these concepts.

No experience necessary.

---

Upcoming Workshops:

Introduction to Programming with Python (April 10-11)
Introduction to Data Science with Python (May 1-2, tentative)
Designing Data Science Course Modules (May 22-23, tentative)

title: R-Ladies Dallas: "Creating gorgeous tables using the gt package" with Pavitra Chakravarty  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the March 1st edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome our very own Pavitra Chakravarty as our guest speaker. Pavitra will introduce the gt package and show how you can easily create beautiful, presentation-ready tables with a few simple lines of code. As a bonus. we will kick off the event with an informative lightning talk about classification and regression trees given by Praveena Matthews!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lightning talk title: Classification and Regression Trees
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Praveena Mathews teaches R for GraduateTutor.com. She is also the founder of R-Ladies Chennai.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Using the `gt` package to create presentation-ready tables
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: Tables are sometimes treated like the step-children of the Vizworld. An after-thought or as place-holders for numbers. For me, tables are the sexiest visualizations in the Viz world; a good table conveys more to me through its simplicity than the sometimes confusing array of colors, shapes and sizes of a plot.

Bio: I am a data engineer at Converging Health who is a also a bench-trained PhD scientist. I use enterprise tools in my day job; don‚Äôt hold that against me. Open source is where my heart is at.

Twitter: @genomixgmailcom

*************************************************************************

title: R-Ladies Dallas: Data Storytelling with Amber Thomas  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the March 16th edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Amber Thomas as our guest speaker. Amber will introduce the topic of data storytelling.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Telling Data Stories at The Pudding
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: At The Pudding, we create data-driven, visual essays. But how do we go from a basic idea all the way to a finished, interactive experience? In this talk, I'll cover where our ideas come from, how we choose which ones to pursue, and our entire process from idea to completion.

Bio: Amber is a Senior Journalist Engineer at The Pudding, where her work focuses primarily on communicating complex topics and ideas, designing and developing data visualizations for the web, and improving the accessibility of information for a general audience. Before starting at The Pudding in 2017, Amber was a marine biologist and a research scientist.

Twitter: twitter.com/ProQuesAsker

Website: amber.rbind.io

title: R-Ladies Milan: SELF LEADERSHIP: PER ESSERE UN VERO LEADER PRIMA BISOGNA CONOSCERSI [Workshop]  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:

A partire da una lunga e approfondita esperienza di lavoro a stretto contatto con le persone, in piccoli e grandi gruppi e organizzazioni, e dalle diverse culture e generazioni, Nancy Cooklin, coach, counselor e formatrice, ha creato un modello chiamato ‚ÄúHuman Leadership‚Äù.

In questo momento pi√π che mai l‚Äôaspetto ‚ÄúHuman‚Äù √® diventato centrale sia nella vita professionale che in quella personale. La chiave sta nell'essere focalizzati e forti emotivamente. title: R-Ladies New York: Focus on Content: Create Enterprise-Worthy Shiny Applications with Periscope  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our March event, Dr. Connie Brett, the CEO, founder, & principal data scientist of Aggregate Genius, Inc. will talk to us about the Periscope package and enterprise-level Shiny apps!

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
6:05 - 6:10 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
6:10 + : Connie's talk on periscope with time for Q&A

--- Talk Abstract ---

"Focus on Content: Create Enterprise-Worthy Shiny Applications with Periscope"
Speaker: Dr. Connie Brett

Abstract: The periscope R package is a framework that you can use to significantly speed up your shiny development ‚Äì whether you are just writing your first collaborative application or taking on a bigger project that will be deployed to many users. Periscope can significantly "up" your Shiny game by jump-starting development in a way that is flexible and robust. This lets you focus on the content of your application, as opposed to the mechanics (and those insidious pitfalls!) of building a shiny application for multiple users.

Bio: Dr. Connie Brett is the CEO, Founder, and Principal Data Scientist of Aggregate Genius Inc. located in BC, Canada. She is experienced in using many types of models and algorithms as well as architecting cutting-edge big-data analytics-integrated platforms. She has submitted publications and patents; contributes to and maintains R packages and frameworks (such as periscope) in the open-source community; and attends and speaks at industry events. With over 20 years spent focusing on producing solid analytical models, software and visualization tools ‚Äì as well as custom IT solutions architecture ‚Äì she continues to carry forward her passion for helping clients realize true business insights from analytics.

---

title: R-Ladies Calgary: Maps and Apps with R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Are you interested in knowing more about R? R is one of the most popular programming languages for data analysis and visualization in fields from biology to banking. In this workshop, you will learn how to use R and R tools to create, load, plot, and analyze spatial data using an example that explores how animals are influenced by the physical world around them. Then, you will learn how to use R Shiny to display your data and analysis on an interactive web app ready for the internet.
This workshop is aimed at attendees with beginner or higher level of programming experience in either R or another programming language. Attendees will benefit from familiarity with the concepts of assigning variables, subsetting arrays/matrices/data tables, and using predefined functions in their language of choice; but those unfamiliar with these concepts are welcome to follow along to see an example of what R can do!

Jori Harrison is a PhD candidate at the University of Calgary where she studies how ecological factors influence environmental DNA. She has a BSc in Biochemistry, is a Professional Biologist with ASPB, and has over four years of experience as a wildlife genetics analyst with environmental consulting companies. She uses R regularly for statistical analysis, DNA sequence studies, and making pretty graphs with clicky buttons.
Danielle Clake is a PhD candidate at the University of Calgary where she studies how bumble bee populations respond to different landscape characteristics. She has a BSc in Environmental Science and a MSc in Conservation biology, and over four years of experience as a geographic information systems (GIS) analyst for environmental consulting and wind power companies. She uses R regularly for statistical analysis and in spatial analyses of landscapes and bumble bee genetics.

***

We are co-organising this workshop in collaboration with WiCS (Women in Computer Science at UofC). WiCS strives to enhance the learning experience of students through the facilitation of meaningful events and opportunities to learn and apply practical and professional skills. We are open to students from all degree levels and backgrounds and aim to provide representation, inclusivity and growth. Their Instagram can be found @wics.uofc and LinkedIn is WiCS U of C.

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: March Meet-up  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Alastair Rushworth (Tesco Bank)

Title: Exploring EDA with R

Abstract: Exploratory data analysis (aka EDA) is one of the most important tools in the data scientist‚Äôs toolkit, while also being one of the hardest to codify and teach. EDA is often understood as an exercise undertaken at the beginning of a data science project, to expose insights and patterns that support, and eventually give way to more formal modeling or statistical analysis. But is this sufficient, or is there more to EDA than that? In this talk I will attempt to dig deeper into what EDA is for and how it can support an iterative process of learning and discovery, while also demonstrating some of the great R packages and tools that I have found useful along the way.

Matthew Higgs

Title: What can data scientists learn from data-driven responses to Covid-19?

Abstract: Data-driven responses to Covid-19 have been developed at speed across the public sector, academia, and commercial sector - leading to a range of successes, failures, and opportunities for lessons to be learned. At the ‚ÄòObservatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19‚Äô (omddac.org.uk) we are analysing key data-driven responses to Covid-19 and collating lessons learned by way of stakeholder interviews, case study analysis, and representative public surveys. In this talk, I will highlight some key findings from our stakeholder interviews and reflect on the role of data science during the Covid-19 pandemic. I will discuss successful applications of data science, ethical issues to be aware of, and what stakeholders *really* think about working with data scientists.

Bio: Matthew Higgs MMath, PhD is a Lecturer in the Department of Computing and Information Sciences at Northumbria University and a Co-Investigator on the UKRI-funded project ‚ÄòObservatory for Monitoring Data-Driven Approaches to Covid-19‚Äô (omddac.org.uk). Since completing his PhD in Computational Statistics and Machine Learning at University College London in 2011, Matthew has worked in technical and non-technical roles in academia, the commercial sector, and the public sector - with a focus on managing diverse stakeholders and developing data-driven products and solutions.

title: LA R users group: [OCRUG X-Post] Virtual Data Science Hackathon - **Signup on Eventbrite  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Cross-post for OCRUG:
***REGISTER ON EVENTBRITE***
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ocrug-virtual-data-science-hackathon-tickets-144355327671

******************************************************************

We are excited to announce that the second Orange Country R Users Group (OCRUG) data science hackathon now has tickets available. It is a weekend-long event.

During this event, we will be exploring an interesting data set, starting from the raw data all the way through to a final "end product" (e.g. a data visualization, an interesting data insight, a predictive model, etc.).

This event is open to all experience levels, from the complete beginner to the highly experienced. Participants will work in teams to "hack" through the data and will present their work at the end of the event for prizes. You are free to create your own team, or we will assist in team creation if you do not have one. This is a great way to network, share, and learn from others.

The main goal of the hackathon is to promote teamwork and foster education and learning in a welcoming environment. Though teams will be competing to present their best work at the end of the event for prizes, communication and providing assistance across teams is highly encouraged. We will provide in-person training during the hackathon and online training prior to the event.

We have set up a GitHub repository that has more information about the hackathon. Such as the schedule; setting up slack and much more. Further information will be provided prior to the event.

All participants must abide by the OCRUG Code of Conduct and R Consortium Code of Conduct.

This will be an online event.

title: LA R users group: LA R Users: April Meeting 2021 - Emily Riederer -  Column Names as Contracts  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
LA R Users Group will have our April meeting online on Zoom (https://usc.zoom.us/j/92828963940).

***Column Names as Contracts***

In this talk, I will explain how controlled vocabularies can be used to form contracts between data producers and data consumers. Explicitly embedding meaning in each component of variable names is a low-tech and low-friction approach which builds a shared understanding of how each field in the dataset is intended to work.
Doing so can offload the burden of data producers by facilitating automated data validation and metadata management. At the same time, data consumers benefit by a reduction in the cognitive load to remember names, a deeper understanding of variable encoding, and opportunities to more efficiently analyze the resulting dataset.
After discussing the theory of controlled vocabulary column-naming and related workflows, I will demonstrate how to implement the creation, upkeep, and application of controlled vocabularies with various softwares, including the R package {convo} and custom SQL templating and testing with dbt.

Bio:
Emily Riederer is a Senior Analytics Manager at Capital One where she leads a team to develop and sustain data products (datamarts, R packages, and dashboards) for business users. Emily blogs at https://emilyriederer.netlify.com/ , is a contributing author to The R Markdown Cookbook (CRC Press) and 97 Things Every Data Engineer Should Know (O‚ÄôReilly - forthcoming), and the developer of the R packages projmgr and convo.

**Code of Conduct**: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R): X-Europe Webinar #18 - How Private and High-Quality Can Synthetic Data Be?  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R)
description:
MEETUP DESCRIPTION

Privacy concerns have been growing over the last 20 years as companies collect more data about their customers. Synthetic data has exploded in popularity as a tool for anonymization, due to its benefits of preserving statistical relationships while severely reducing the risk of re-identification. Generating synthetic data is easy with many companies offering solutions alongside an active research field constantly publishing new algorithms. When you start to work with synthetic data, many questions arise over the accuracy and privacy-preserving characteristics of your synthetic data.

In this talk, we will go over a few topics. We outline why privacy is
important and how synthetic data prevails over many classical
anonymization techniques. Next, we look at open source tools in
measuring the quality of a synthetic dataset. Leading into our next
topic of introducing VirtualDataLab, a Python open source tool
developed by MOSTLY AI. (Me included!) Lastly, we go over some best practices for picking a synthetic data generator.

### REGISTRATION INFO

-->>> Registration link: https://synthetic-data-privacy.carrd.co/ <<<--
Please also RSVP here on the Meetup Page.

### Our Speaker

Victoria Tran
https://www.linkedin.com/in/vickictran/

Victoria is a data scientist for MOSTLY AI, a synthetic data startup
based in Vienna, Austria. Previously, she‚Äôs worked as a data scientist
for various mobile game companies based in Europe and Canada. She‚Äôs passionate about making data accessible and easy to understand for all.

### ABOUT THE X-EUROPE DATA SCIENCE WEBINARS

X-Europe Webinar Series is a joint online event of Vienna Data Science Group, Frankfurt Data Science, Budapest Data Science Meetup, BCN Analytics, Budapest.AI, Barcelona Data Science and Machine Learning Meetup, Budapest Deep Learning Reading Seminar, Warsaw R Users Group, PyData Slovakia, and Data Scientists Ireland.

title: Santa Barbara R Users Group: [OCRUG X-Post] Virtual Data Science Hackathon, United States, US/Canada
description:
**Signup on Eventbrite not Meetup**

Details

We are excited to announce that the second Orange Country R Users Group (OCRUG) data science hackathon now has tickets available. It is a weekend-long event.

**********************
You can purchase tickets on eventbrite.
https://tinyurl.com/ocrug-hackathon-2021-05
**********************

During this event, we will be exploring an interesting data set, starting from the raw data all the way through to a final "end product" (e.g. a data visualization, an interesting data insight, a predictive model, etc.).

This event is open to all experience levels, from the complete beginner to the highly experienced. Participants will work in teams to "hack" through the data and will present their work at the end of the event for prizes. You are free to create your own team, or we will assist in team creation if you do not have one. This is a great way to network, share, and learn from others.

The main goal of the hackathon is to promote teamwork and foster education and learning in a welcoming environment. Though teams will be competing to present their best work at the end of the event for prizes, communication and providing assistance across teams is highly encouraged. We will provide in-person training during the hackathon and online training prior to the event.

We have set up a GitHub repository that has more information about the hackathon. Such as the schedule; setting up slack and much more. Further information will be provided prior to the event.

All participants must abide by the OCRUG Code of Conduct and R Consortium Code of Conduct.

This will be an online event.

title: Inland Northwest R User Group (INRUG): Using R to analyze and model COVID-19 cases  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Speaker: Dr. Krisztian Magori

Title: Using R to analyze and model COVID-19 cases

Abstract: Many years from now, we will all think back to what we were doing during the COVID-19 pandemic, and how we contributed to resolving it. In my presentation, I will show you three small projects I conducted related to the pandemic, and look for your feedback. First, I analyzed COVID-19 case trends across the State of Washington, particularly in Spokane, in order for myself to see behind daily case counts, and still looking for ways to expand that. Second, I tested the oft-heard suggestion that increased case numbers in the fall of 2020 were simply due to increased testing, using bootstrapping methods. Finally, I developed a stochastic, spatially explicit model to simulate COVID-19 transmission within a facility, such as a dorm, with visualization conducted in R.

Speaker Profile: Krisztian Magori,Ph.D., is a Associate Professor of Biostatistics at the Department of Biology at Eastern Washington University. He teaches biostatistics using R at both the undergraduate and graduate level, and consults with faculty and students on statistical analysis of their datasets. In addition, he is a disease ecologist, focusing on ticks and mosquitoes, when we don't have a pandemic that's more important.

title: AalborgRUG: Graphical models with sparse conditional probability tables in R  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
Password to the zoom meeting: aalborgrug

The talk will include

- A brief introduction to graphical models
- Discussion of R packages dealing with graphical models
- Sparse conditional probability tables
- A novel method for handling inference via JTA in massive networks

Graphical models is a family of probability distributions that can be interpreted using directed or undirected graphs in which each node represents a random variable; an edge between two variables indicates a relationship between these. Such a graphical representation is convenient, since, for high-dimensional problems the local interpretation of a subset of variables can be interpreted in the sub-graph induced by these variables and variables connected to these. By exploiting the graph-theoretic representation, general algorithms can be used for computing marginal and conditional probabilities. For problems large enough, it can be impossible to compute such probabilities without exploiting the graphical representation. Of particular importance for calculations of probabilities in graphical models is the Junction Tree Algorithm (JTA).

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Stacked Ensemble Modeling with Tidy Data Principles  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our April Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Stacked ensemble modeling is a statistical modeling technique that involves training a model to combine the outputs of many constituent models. The technique has been shown to increase predictive performance in a variety of settings. This talk will introduce {stacks}, a free and open-source R software package for stacked ensemble modeling that aligns with tidy data principles. The package‚Äôs functionality is closely aligned with the {tidymodels}, a collection of packages providing a unified interface to diverse statistical modeling techniques.

Simon Couch is a developer on open source R packages for statistical modeling. He is currently an undergraduate studying statistics at Reed College and formerly an intern at RStudio. Simon was awarded the 2021 John M. Chambers Statistical Software Award for {stacks}.

Dr. Rachael Tatman is a senior developer advocate at Rasa, where she helps developers use open source software to build great conversational AI projects. Before that she was at Kaggle (part of Google) and completed a PhD in Linguistics.

title: Oslo useR! Group: Get Your Results Faster With {future}  [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
The {future} package offers a unifying framework to distributed computing in R. It lets you run exactly the same code ‚Äì and achieve exactly the same results ‚Äì sequentially on your laptop, in parallel on your laptop, in the cloud, or on large computing clusters. In this talk, √òystein will highlight various ways {future} lets you do your data science tasks more efficiently, from file system operations and preparation of large datasets to statistics and machine learning tasks like cross-validation, bootstrapping, and simulations. He'll focus particularly on functional programming with {future.apply} and {furrr} in parallel on a decent laptop, but will also touch upon cloud and cluster computing and package development.

[Bio]
√òystein S√∏rensen is an Associate Professor in Statistics at the Department of Psychology, University of Oslo (UiO). He works on both applied data analysis projects within cognitive neuroscience as well as development of new statistical tools, typically involving generalized additive models, and he is the author of four R packages. He received his PhD from the UiO in 2014, after which he worked as a data scientist in Storebrand and NextBridge analytics prior to joining UiO in 2018. His homepage is https://osorensen.rbind.io/.

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by Brighton R - Shiny in production with {golem}  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

BrightonR is back for the first virtual meetup of 2021!

Please sign up for the event on our EventBrite page: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/brighton-r-april-meetup-tickets-146323695111

We're delighted to host Chris Beeley, Senior Data Scientist at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust, who will speak about the working practices that have evolved at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust that are focused on allowing a group of data scientists to collaborate on Shiny applications, ensuring that the code that they write is robust, error free, and easily deployable. Shiny applications are produced according to best practice as defined by the {golem} package, and the modularity inherent in that approach is key to making the applications robust as well as allowing the git and GitHub based collaboration to work effectively.

A number of examples of modular and {golem} based development will be discussed, including some of technical hurdles and challenges faced by developers who are beginning to use Shiny modules, and some of the advanced features of Shiny and {golem} that can make building robust and scalable applications easier

description:

[Abstract]
In this talk, I (Micka√´l Canouil, https://m.canouil.fr) will chronicle my journey towards a more transparent and reproducible work environment. I will talk about the changes and improvements that I have implemented in my team, detailing the transition of infrastructure used when I arrived to an infrastructure using Docker and and the {renv} R package.

[Bio]

I have developed a few R packages, and although some are not very useful, they are most definitely entertaining (i.e., https://github.com/mcanouil/ggpacman/).

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by R Lille - How To Build A Package With The "Rmd First" Method  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

[Abstract]
You know how to build a Rmardown, you were said or would like to put your work in a R package, but you think this is too much work? You do not understand where to put what and when? What if writing a Rmd was the same as writing a package? Follow the "Rmd-first" method and let {fusen} guide you to build a documented and tested package, to ensure the sustainability and sharing of your work.

[Bio]
S√©bastien Rochette (@statnmap) is R trainer and consultant at ThinkR (https://rtask.thinkr.fr/).

He participates in the development of open-source R packages proposed on GitHub by ThinkR (https://github.com/thinkR-open/) and himself, including {fusen} and {attachment}. He also has created multiple internal packages for ThinkR and different clients.

He gave different presentations and tutorials on package development with the 'Rmd first' method as summed up in "Rmd first: When development starts with documentation" (https://rtask.thinkr.fr/when-development-starts-with-documentation/) and blogs about R on his website (https://statnmap.com/).

He is co-author of the book "Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps" (https://engineering-shiny.org/) that promotes an adapted RMDD method for Shiny application using {golem}.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: CalgaryR: Exploring Alberta‚Äôs Solar Resource through R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
We're happy to have a wonderful speaker and topic to start our first virtual meetup. Abed W Ayyad (https://manipulativegerbil.blogspot.com/) will share his exploration of solar PV and how R can be used for solar PV in Alberta.

Solar energy converted to electricity (photovoltaic, or PV, electricity) seems almost too good to be true when it comes to thinking about ways of reducing global carbon emissions. According to a widely repeated claim, one hour's worth of the solar radiation which falls on the earth's surface could meet human energy needs for one year. Though impressive and technically "correct", this is far from being a practical or meaningful calculation. So how much carbon-neutral electricity could someone sitting in the Canadian prairies actually harvest from the sunshine falling on their backyard?

R lends itself perfectly to the data intensive task of planning and predicting the amount of solar insolation which falls on a given location, and the electricity which one can expect to harvest from it. Following a (very) broad introduction to solar energy and photovoltaics, we will explore a number of packages available in R which make it possible to access and analyse publicly available data on solar insolation, and to understand what this might mean in terms of solar PV potential at a site in Alberta. We will accomplish the latter by doing a walk-through of an example using the nasapower package available in CRAN, as well as a number of the graphics and GIS-related packages also available in R. This talk, aimed at a wide audience of R users, will illustrate why Alberta is a surprisingly perfect location for solar PV deployment and how you can convince yourself of that using R.

About the speaker: Abed has used R in a variety of settings for seven years now, for GIS/cartography applications, data analysis and linear optimisation. There are many reasons to love R, but the community of users is definitely one of the biggest. Last September, Edmonton became the 10th city which Abed has called home during his life. Abed is looking forward to discovering more of the city, and to cycling to some parks and lakes as the summer goes on and the days get longer.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: The extendr project: Integrating R and Rust  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
We have our second Rust talk in three months, this time about integrating R and Rust.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack.

About the Talk:
Rust is a relatively new programming language that is rapidly gaining in popularity. It is designed to be suitable for low-level system programming with high performance and low overhead while providing modern abstractions and protection from undefined behavior. The most common application scenarios for Rust are those that otherwise might be suitable for C or C++. As such, Rust may be a good choice for writing extensions to high-level interactive languages such as R. The extendr project was founded with the goal to make writing Rust extensions to R as easy and painless as possible. At the same time, extendr also enables the reverse use case, writing standalone Rust programs that call R code and take advantage of the R runtime. This talk will provide an overview of the extendr API and its key design choices, and it will highlight simple use cases and known pitfalls. The talk is meant primarily as an introduction to Rust for current R users. However, experienced Rust programmers who want to branch out into data science and statistical programming may also find this talk helpful.

About Claus:
Claus Wilke is the Jane and Roland Blumberg Centennial Professor in Molecular Evolution at The¬†University of Texas at Austin. He holds a PhD in Theoretical Physics from the University of¬†Bochum in Germany, and he received postdoctoral training in biological physics in the lab of Chris¬†Adami at Caltech. Claus Wilke has published extensively in the areas of computational biology,¬†evolutionary biology, protein biochemistry, and virology. He has also authored several popular R¬†packages used for data visualization, such as cowplot, ggridges, and ggtext, and he is a regular¬†contributor to the package ggplot2.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: April meeting: Share your favourite thing about R or RStudio  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
There is a sheer endless amount of things to know about R and RStudio ‚Äì and only this many things you will ever get to know. This holds especially true once you've found a workaround for doing something particular because you're little likely to search for more efficient ways of handling that matter. In our experience, the best way to learn the little things that make an impact is through other useRs.

For our April meetup, we would like to draw from the experiences of other useRs' and ask each of the participants to show their favorite thing about R or RStudio. Whether it's an underused feature, a package, a function or a shortcut you discovered - let us know! If it is a brand new feature of the latest version of R or RStudio ‚Äì we're happy to hear about it!

There is no need to prepare a fancy presentation on something highly sophisticated. Just take a minute and think about the things that you really like and want others to know about. As always, R users of all levels of expertise are welcome. There is always something new to learn for everyone.

title: R-Ladies Philly: 2021 Datathon Conclusion: Exploring Judicial Patterns  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
The 2021 RLadies Philly hackathon is focused on exploring judicial patterns in Philadelphia courts. Our partner, the Judge Accountability Table (JAT), has provided a subset of deidentified data related to public court dockets for defendants in Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania, to enable participants to hone thier data science skills by:

- Exploring and describing this rich, messy data more completely
- Stratifying data (e.g., comparing simple, low-severity charges with one another and complex, violent crime allegations with one another)
- Answering specific questions, or discovering what additional work or information would be required to be able to answer these questions
- Analyzing sparsity / missingness and discovering what the public interest is in ensuring freedom of information
- Understanding predictive factors in carceral outcomes (e.g. does age / sex / race correlate with bail amount?)

At this meetup, groups will present their results and discuss their experiences.

title: R-Ladies Auckland: Creating Tables for R Markdown with kableExtra, New Zealand, Australia
description:
Join us for an in-person meetup to learn about creating tables for reports in R Markdown, hosted by Izzy Johnson!

All levels of R users (including beginners!) are welcome.

Time: 6:00 arrival for a 6:30pm start and 7:45pm finish.

What to bring: Yourself! Optionally you can bring a laptop with R installed if you'd like to code along with the presentation.

Plots are great, but sometimes tables can be a useful way to display data as well. Izzy will talk briefly about a few ways to create tables to display data in R, and then walk though how the kableExtra package can help customise your tables, and make them look cleaner and easier to read when creating reports and summaries in R Markdown.

This meeting will be hosted by Xero, on Saint Georges Bay Road in Parnell.

If you have any questions or problems, don't hesitate to contact Izzy Johnson through meet-up!

As with all our meetups, please be aware of and read the Code of Conduct before attending.
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {R-Ladies Toolbox Series} Part 4: Version Control  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
R-Ladies Toolbox Series - Essentials for women and minority genders in academia, science and data analysis presents:

--> Version Control by Christin Zasada (R-Ladies Global Team, R-Ladies Berlin) <--

Title: Make your first merge request

Talk description: Version control can be tempting at the beginning. Git and GitHub are a great resource of tools and code. Worldwide people are contributing to each other projects and driving R package development. In my talk I would like to introduce you to a simplified but effective strategy for shared code development. We'll walk through your first merge request using command line and Gitlabs browser interface. Make sure that you have your GitLab account ready.

Calling all students, academics, and women in science! R-Ladies Freiburg presents a five-part guest series aimed at women and gender minorities in academia, science and data analysis, from first semester students to tenured researchers. Leading R-Ladies from around the world will lead us through the most fundamental steps to studying and working in academia, from analyzing results, to presenting them clearly, ensuring their reproducibility, and keeping track of all your changes. The series will close with a panel discussion from women around the world, who will speak about their experiences with science.

This series is funded by the ‚ÄúP√§dagogische Hochschule Freiburg‚Äù, the University of Education in Freiburg.

Participants who take part in all five meetups can receive a certificate of participation.

Everyone is welcome to join and we hope for a warm exchange between students and researchers, as well as R-Ladies from the wider community.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {Part 4: Visualization} From Zero to (s)Hero: Multi-part intro to R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Just getting involved with R or want to level up your skills? Have you used base-R but are still trying to wrap your head around the tidyverse "pipe" (%>%)? Have a messy dataset and don't know where to start? Seen beautiful visualizations on Twitter and want to make your own?

If you‚Äôve answered ‚Äòyes‚Äô to at least one of these questions, fear no more! In this monthly workshop series, we will walk you through the fundamental uses of tidyverse and ggplot at your own pace with the help of hands-on exercises. Tidyverse and ggplot are a classic combination of R packages that allow you to "wrangle" your unwieldy data into whatever shape you need and creative beautiful and informative visualizations.

Over the course of this series, you will learn the most useful features of R Studio and R Markdown, how to read in and explore data, and transform it into a shape that's easy to work with. You will be able to create new columns and summary tables, subset interesting rows or columns, and combine and reshape dataframes. We will also dive into ggplot, one of the best tools for creating great-looking bar charts, scatterplots, and more!

This is (currently) a five-part series, aimed at total beginners and/or people with some experience in base-R or tidyverse who are looking to freshen up or expand their skills. Feel free to join at any point, we will briefly review the previous topic at the beginning of each session.

January 20th {Part 1}: The R & R-Studio ABCs (packages, files, data types & basic data exploration)
February 17th {Part 2}: Tidy data & introduction to data wrangling (tibbles, renaming, reordering, subsetting)
March 17th {Part 3}: Data wrangling with dplyr (new columns, if-else statements, summary tables, joining dataframes)
April 21st {Part 4}: Introduction to visualizations with ggplot (line graphs, bar charts, scatterplots, histograms, and more!)
May 19th {Part 5}: Advanced topics in wrangling and ggplot (pivoting, ggplot style options, etc.)

Please install R and R-Studio before joining: https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/starting.html

Image by the amazing @allison_horst: https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations

title: AthensR: Shiny in production with {golem} - Brighton R  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
We're delighted to host Chris Beeley, Senior Data Scientist at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust, who will speak about the working practices that have evolved at Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust that are focused on allowing a group of data scientists to collaborate on Shiny applications, ensuring that the code that they write is robust, error free, and easily deployable. Shiny applications are produced according to best practice as defined by the {golem} package, and the modularity inherent in that approach is key to making the applications robust as well as allowing the git and GitHub based collaboration to work effectively.

A number of examples of modular and {golem} based development will be discussed, including some of technical hurdles and challenges faced by developers who are beginning to use Shiny modules, and some of the advanced features of Shiny and {golem} that can make building robust and scalable applications easier.

title: AthensR: My Journey To Transparency And Reproducibility [R Lille]   [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
In this talk, I (Micka√´l Canouil, https://m.canouil.fr) will chronicle my journey towards a more transparent and reproducible work environment. I will talk about the changes and improvements that I have implemented in my team, detailing the transition of infrastructure used when I arrived to an infrastructure using Docker and and the {renv} R package.

[Bio]
I am a biostatistician (Ph.D.) and the head of a small team within a research laboratory, working primarily on the genetics of diabetes and obesity.
I have developed a few R packages, and although some are not very useful, they are most definitely entertaining (i.e., https://github.com/mcanouil/ggpacman/).
I also enjoy watching movies and playing with R (https://m.canouil.fr/imdb_ratings/).

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: AthensR: How To Build A Package With The "Rmd First" Method [R Lille]   [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
You know how to build a Rmarkdown, you were said or would like to put your work in a R package, but you think this is too much work? You do not understand where to put what and when? What if writing a Rmd was the same as writing a package? Follow the "Rmd-first" method and let {fusen} guide you to build a documented and tested package, to ensure the sustainability and sharing of your work.

[Bio]
S√©bastien Rochette (@statnmap) is R trainer and consultant at ThinkR (https://rtask.thinkr.fr/).

He participates in the development of open-source R packages proposed on GitHub by ThinkR (https://github.com/thinkR-open/) and himself, including {fusen} and {attachment}. He also has created multiple internal packages for ThinkR and different clients.

He gave different presentations and tutorials on package development with the 'Rmd first' method as summed up in "Rmd first: When development starts with documentation" (https://rtask.thinkr.fr/when-development-starts-with-documentation/) and blogs about R on his website (https://statnmap.com/).

He is co-author of the book "Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps" (https://engineering-shiny.org/) that promotes an adapted RMDD method for Shiny application using {golem}.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: This month, I learned ...  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
No matter how much you learn, there always seems to be something new in the world of R. How do you keep abreast of the changes, and keep your knowledge up-to-date?

In this talk, I'll share some things I learned this month, and how I went about it. It will cover an eclectic mix of new things from packages in the tidyverse, R and RStudio.

I hope you'll either learn something new, or learn a new strategy for staying up to date.

Charlotte Wickham is Data Scientist, instructor at Oregon State University, and specialist in R training. I'm available for R training and data science consulting.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Exploring Our Universe Through Sight & Sound (or Touch!)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Information of cosmic objects doesn't have to be just a two-dimensional snap shot. We can transform these data to be able to listen, feel, or (virtually) move through the cosmos through virtual reality and even holograms. Such data taken from telescopes in space ‚Äì often in light invisible to the human eye ‚Äì can be translated into many different forms to help provide access to some of space‚Äôs most interesting and mysterious objects. Dr. Kimberly Arcand, from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, will take you to the debris from an exploded star through sound, walk you through the core of our Milky Way virtually, discuss feeling vibrations of a stellar nursery, and help you experience our universe anew.

For information about our speaker, Kimberly Arcand, please go to https://www.kimarcand.com/about.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Lessons from Plants  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Lessons from Plants (https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/lessons-from-plants-beronda-l-montgomery/1137725290).

An exploration of how plant behavior and adaptation offer valuable insights for human thriving.

We know that plants are important. They maintain the atmosphere by absorbing carbon dioxide and producing oxygen. They nourish other living organisms and supply psychological benefits to humans as well, improving our moods and beautifying the landscape around us. But plants don‚Äôt just passively provide. They also take action.

Beronda L. Montgomery explores the vigorous, creative lives of organisms often treated as static and predictable. In fact, plants are masters of adaptation. They ‚Äúknow‚Äù what and who they are, and they use this knowledge to make a way in the world. Plants experience a kind of sensation that does not require eyes or ears. They distinguish kin, friend, and foe, and they are able to respond to ecological competition despite lacking the capacity of fight-or-flight. Plants are even capable of transformative behaviors that allow them to maximize their chances of survival in a dynamic and sometimes unfriendly environment.

Lessons from Plants enters into the depth of botanic experience and shows how we might improve human society by better appreciating not just what plants give us but also how they achieve their own purposes. What would it mean to learn from these organisms, to become more aware of our environments and to adapt to our own worlds by calling on perception and awareness? Montgomery‚Äôs meditative study puts before us a question with the power to reframe the way we live: What would a plant do?

Description:

title: R-Ladies RTP: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

The dataset we will explore will be posted before we meet.

Agenda:
7:00 - 7:15 pm Meet & Greet
7:15 - 8:30 pm #tidytuesday
8:30 - 9:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a cozy beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: R-Ladies RTP: Common Statistical Tests in R (t-tests, linear regression, ANOVA)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
By the end of this event, participants will be able to perform one- and two-sample t-tests, linear regression, and ANOVA. We will discuss how to understand the output and look at diagnostics of the tests. We will not focus on data cleaning and data for examples will already be in ideal format. If time allows, we will discuss logistic regression.

Agenda:
‚Ä¢ 6:30 pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
‚Ä¢ 6:45 pm - 8:15 pm - Examples and practice
‚Ä¢ 8:15 pm - 8:30 pm - Wrap up

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have little to no experience programming in R. We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Stephanie at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Introduction to Time Series in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join R-Ladies St. Louis as we welcome Laura Rose from Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals. Laura Rose is a Manager of Demand at Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals, where she forecasts Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API). She has previous experience in economic analysis and Consumer Packaged Goods forecasting. Laura has a M.A. in Economics from the University of Missouri-St. Louis. She enjoys using R for time series analysis, building Shiny apps, and automating data analysis tasks.

Laura will teach an introductory workshop on time series for this Meetup. She suggests having the several R packages installed prior to the workshop and we will send out the code and data files via email prior to the workshop.

Packages to install:
tsibble
feasts
fable
tidyverse
readxl

Looking forward to seeing you there!

title: R-Ladies Tbilisi: Bookclub - Chapter 3: Data Visualisation Part I  [Virtual] , Georgia, Asia
description:
R-Ladies Tbilisi bookclub is continuing its meetings on Hadley Wickham's and Garret Grolemund's "R for Data Science" (https://r4ds.had.co.nz/).

On April 9, Eka Oshkhereli will present the book's Chapter 3 up to and including subsection 3.6. This is on data visualisation. https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html

Please read the sections 3.1 - 3.6 to be better prepared for the session and exercises. We will go through the exercises together. We start at 19.30 Tbilisi time!

Please RSVP on Meetup or sign up at this link (even if you want to attend as a listener only):
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1lufZ5eKEeNyinYbPqytVchdbkx5SwS6eKVfnIvEoqXk/

title: R-Ladies Seattle: git through April: Command line git  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us over lunch @ noon for 4 hands-on workshops using version control with git and GitHub.

**This week**

Command line git with Kim Dill-McFarland, Katie Jolly, Jenny Smith

**Content**

Working in command line git to make repositories, track files, and review versions. This content is based on the Carpentries 'Version control with git' (http://swcarpentry.github.io/git-novice/)

All workshop materials can be found at https://github.com/kdillmcfarland/2021-04-02-r-ladies-seattle-online/tree/gh-pages/_episodes/R-ladies

**Audience**

This workshop is meant for novice git users and no prior experience is required. Priority registration will be given to those 1) attending all 4 sessions and 2) local Washington R-Ladies members.

We will be working in command line so those without experience may wish to review basic Unix commands (recommend lessons 1-3 at http://swcarpentry.github.io/shell-novice/)

**Prior to the workshop**

To prepare for this session:
- Install git https://git-scm.com/downloads
- Make a GitHub account https://github.com/

Or to prepare for all sessions:
- Install git https://git-scm.com/downloads
- Make a GitHub account https://github.com/
- Install GitHub Desktop https://desktop.github.com/
- Install R https://www.r-project.org/
- Install RStudio (free) https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

If you have issues with install, an instructor will be on the event Zoom 30 minutes prior to the workshop

title: R-Ladies Seattle: How to Give a Good Conference or Meetup Talk  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us for a discussion about coming up with, designing, and delivering a good talk!

Goals:
Help R-Ladies see themselves as experts and speakers
Demystify the process of applying to speak at conferences
Provide tips and resources for speaking at different types of events and formats
Alert R-Ladies Seattle members and others to upcoming opportunities
Have more people speak at R-Ladies!

Guests:
Dr. Kate Hertweck, Bioinformatics Training Manager at Fred Hutch
Dr. Marie Vendettuoli, Senior Statistical Programmer at Fred Hutch
Kara Woo, Kara Woo, Senior Data Science Engineer at InsightRX

Monica Gerber, R-Ladies Seattle Co-Organizer
Katie Jolly, R-Ladies Seattle Co-Organizer

Moderator:
Isabella Vel√°squez, R-Ladies Seattle Co-Organizer

title: R-Ladies Seattle: git through April: GitHub GUI and RStudio  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada

description:

**This week**

Collaborating in GitHub with Madison Swain-Bowden, Pamela Moriarty, Katie Jolly
